abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Landmine Clearance Project
            was rated as satisfactory with an uncertain sustainability.
            The project has been successful in achieving its physical
            objectives and relatively successful in its institutional
            ones. The major factors affecting the project were: a) lack
            of available experience on how to handle mine clearing
            activities; b) the lack of competitive market conditions for
            demining services; and c) conflicting approaches toward mine
            clearing. Six key lessons were learned. The Bank can have a
            comparative advantage in stand-alone demining projects. This
            comparative advantage lies more in institution building and
            developing a commercial demining capacity than on carrying
            out mine-clearing training or mine awareness programs, for
            which others have more experience. Projects should integrate
            more coordination and adequate division of tasks among
            institutions, especially the United Nations. It is crucial
            to focus, in the immediate post-conflict period, on
            information collection and mapping as a prerequisite to well
            planned priority mine clearing. Commercial approaches to
            demining have proved to be much more productive that any
            other method used for this purpose. Clear technical
            specifications and close monitoring and supervision
            arrangements are key to a proper implementation of
            mine-clearing supervision programs.
